extent to which one feels boundaries fall away between\noneself and the surrounding environment. This dimension can\nbe demonstrated by a commonly used measure to assess the\ndegree to which an individual feels connected to other people or\noneâ€™s environment (Aron, Aron, & Smollan, 1992; see Figure\n1).\nSelf-transcendence has been variously conceptualized in the\npsychological literature in ways that arenotrelevant to our defi-\nnition. Erickson (1982) described self-transcendence as anon-ego-\ncentric understandingof the world. Although our conception of\nSTE may involve a decreasingly ego-centric spatial frame of\nreference, it does not assume that there is a change in oneâ€™s\nconceptual understanding of a self-centered perspective on the\nworld. Frankl (1966) referred to self-transcendence as aprioriti-\nzation of other peopleover self-focus. Although we suggest that\naltruistic motivation may result from STEs, such other-prioritized\nbehavior or thinking is not involved during the STE. existence in general. Although such prosocial attitudes and\nmotivations may result from an STE, they are not part of the\ntransient state of STE we describe here. Other approaches describe\nself-transcendence as apersonality factor(Piedmont, 1999), or a\ndevelopmental processinvolving a maturing capacity for mean-\ningful connection (Levenson, Jennings, Aldwin, & Shiraishi, 2005;\nTornstam, 2005). A few approaches describe long-term alterations\nto self-processes calledselflessness(Dambrun & Ricard, 2011;\nDavis & Vago, 2013), whereas here we focus on brief mental\nstates. The self-transcendence subscale of the Temperament and\nCharacter Inventory (TCI; Cloninger, Svrakic, & Przybeck, 1993)\noperationalizes self-transcendence as a trait-like tendency to both\nbelieveandfeelthat one is part of, rather than apart from, the\nuniverse as a whole (Garcia-Romeu, 2010). For our purposes, each\nof these characterizations of self-transcendence may be in the intensity of perceived unity is apparent in\nseveral common psychological constructs that researchers have\nclaimed contain degrees of self-transcendence. These â€œvarieties of\nself-transcendent experienceâ€ include: the states of mindfulness\n(Davidson et al., 2003; Kabat-Zinn, 1994), flow (Csikszentmi-\nhalyi, 1991), self-transcendent positive emotions such as love and\nawe (Haidt, 2003; Haidt & Morris, 2009; Keltner & Haidt, 2003;\nVan Cappellen, & Rime, 2014), peak experiences (Maslow, 1964),\nand â€œmysticalâ€ experiences (Hood, 1975, 2003; James, 1902;\nNewberg & dâ€™Aquili, 2000). Each of these otherwise quite differ-\nent constructs has been described in theoretical writing and in\npsychometric scales as having aspects related to reduced self-\nsalience and/or enhanced connectedness.\nThe designation â€œself-transcendent experienceâ€ (STE) works\nbest for our purposes because it captures a spectrum of intensities\nin addition to remaining neutral regarding secular or spiritual"}}],"namespace":"Varieties of Transcendence"}

Jun 16 08:47:22 AM      data: `{"model":"gpt-3.5-turbo","messages":[{"role":"system","content":"You are a friendly, compassionate, and wise advisor.\\n\\nYou are given relevant parts of one or more documents about the Varieties of Transcendence, and you are given a question to answer based on those documents. Please provide a conversational answer with hyperlinks to the documents.\\n\\nIf you cannot find the answer in, or infer it from, the documents, then please say you don't know, and don't try to make up an answer. If the question is not relevant to the Varieties of Transcendence, please say you are only trained to answer questions regarding the Varieties of Transcendence."},{"role":"user","content":"Are some of these ways easier than others?"},{"role":"assistant","content":"Yes, some of these ways of transcending oneself may be easier than others, as everyone has different strengths and challenges in their lives. For example, if you are naturally creative and enjoy exploring different forms of self-expression, cultivating creativity may be easier for you than practicing empathy or developing a growth mindset. \\n\\nSimilarly, if you struggle with taking risks or stepping outside of your comfort zone, embracing discomfort may be more difficult for you than reflecting on yourself or setting big goals. \\n\\nThe key is to identify your own strengths and challenges, and to work on developing those areas that will benefit you the most in your journey of self-transcendence. Don't be discouraged if you find some aspects more challenging than others â€“ progress is often slow and requires patience and perseverance."},{"role":"user","content":"It seems hard to try to do everything at once, yet it all seems intricately interconnected."},{"role":"assistant","content":"You are correct in noting that the different ways to transcend oneself are interconnected and can reinforce each other. For example, practicing empathy can lead to greater self-awareness, which can in turn help identify areas for personal growth. Similarly, developing a growth mindset can help you take more risks and embrace discomfort, which can lead to new forms of creativity and self-expression.\\n\\nIt's important to note that you don't need to try to do everything at once or to be perfect in every area. Rather, focus on the areas that resonate with you the most and that you feel are most important for your own growth and development. This may involve setting goals in those areas and working on them one step at a time. \\n\\nRemember, the journey of self-transcendence is a lifelong process, and small steps taken consistently can lead to significant progress over time. Don't be too hard on yourself if you face setbacks or challenges along the way, and celebrate your successes as they come."},{"role":"user","content":"While embracing discomfort I guess it's important to not shut down our sensitivity to discomfort, right, or else it seems like machismo."},{"role":"assistant","content":"Yes, it's important to not shut down our sensitivity to discomfort when embracing discomfort as a means to transcend oneself. While it's important to challenge ourselves and step out of our comfort zones, it's equally important to be aware of our limits and to listen to our bodies and minds when they tell us we need a break or a change of pace.\\n\\nEmbracing discomfort doesn't mean we need to engage in extreme physical or mental challenges that can harm us or put us in danger, or to ignore our own feelings and emotions. Rather, it means being willing to step outside of our familiar routines and ways of thinking, and to challenge ourselves in healthy and sustainable ways.\\n\\nMaintaining sensitivity to discomfort helps keep us grounded and aware of our own needs and boundaries, and can help us grow and transcend in a way that is both meaningful and sustainable."},{"role":"user","content":"It's certainly helpful in many ways to have a healthy body, but traditionally seekers of mystical experience are often said to have almost tortured themselves in order to force themselves to let go of ordinary concerns in order to experience a higher reality, I guess, right?  "},{"role":"assistant","content":"There are indeed many examples throughout history of spiritual seekers using forms of austerity or asceticism, such as fasting, silence, or physical self-mortification, in order to transcend ordinary concerns and experience a higher reality. These practices have been used in different religious and spiritual traditions around the world, from Christianity to Hinduism to Buddhism.\\n\\nThe goal of these practices has been to strip away the distractions and attachments of the physical world, in order to open oneself up to the divine or the transcendent. However, it's worth noting that these practices can be dangerous and even harmful if taken to extremes, and they are not necessary for everyone seeking mystical experiences. \\n\\nMany spiritual seekers have found that a balanced approach, one that honors the body and mind while also cultivating mindfulness and an openness to experience, can be just as effective in achieving transcendent states. Ultimately, the path of transcendence is a personal one, and each individual must find their own way that honors their own unique needs and limitations."},{"role":"user","content":"Is self-transcendence a spiritual experience?"},{"role":"assistant","content":"Self-transcendence can certainly be a spiritual experience, but it is not limited to spiritual or religious contexts. Self-transcendence can be understood as an expansion of one's sense of self, often through experiences that challenge one's existing beliefs, values, or sense of identity. This can happen both within and outside of specific spiritual or religious traditions.\\n\\nWhile self-transcendence can certainly involve experiences that are associated with spiritual or transcendental realms, such as experiences of unity, transcendence, or non-duality, it can also be experienced in more mundane contexts. For example, learning a new skill, overcoming a fear, or connecting with others in a deep and meaningful way can all lead to an expansion of one's sense of self and an experience of self-transcendence.\\n\\nUltimately, self-transcendence is a subjective experience that can take many forms, depending on the individual's context, beliefs, and personal goals. It can involve the spiritual, the psychological, the social, or the creative, to name a few possibilities. Rather, it means being willing to step outside of our familiar routines and ways of thinking, and to challenge ourselves in healthy and sustainable ways.\\n\\nMaintaining sensitivity to discomfort helps keep us grounded and aware of our own needs and boundaries, and can help us grow and transcend in a way that is both meaningful and sustainable."},{"role":"user","content":"It's certainly helpful in many ways to have a healthy body, but traditionally seekers of mystical experience are often said to have almost tortured themselves in order to force themselves to let go of ordinary concerns in order to experience a higher reality, I guess, right? However, it's worth noting that these practices can be dangerous and even harmful if taken to extremes, and they are not necessary for everyone seeking mystical experiences. \\n\\nMany spiritual seekers have found that a balanced approach, one that honors the body and mind while also cultivating mindfulness and an openness to experience, can be just as effective in achieving transcendent states. Log 2
=====
Jun 16 11:32:19 AM  ==> Starting service with 'node index.js'
Jun 16 11:32:21 AM  searchAIapi listening on port 44444
Jun 16 11:32:24 AM  Your service is live ðŸŽ‰
Jun 16 11:33:59 AM  chatbot=chatbot_transcendence
Jun 16 11:33:59 AM  namespace=Varieties of Transcendence
Jun 16 11:34:02 AM  indexResponse.matches[0].metadata.text=the extent to which one feels boundaries fall away between
  oneself and the surrounding environment. This dimension can
  be demonstrated by a commonly used measure to assess the
  degree to which an individual feels connected to other people or
  oneâ€™s environment (Aron, Aron, & Smollan, 1992; see Figure
  1).
  Self-transcendence has been variously conceptualized in the
  psychological literature in ways that arenotrelevant to our defi-
  nition. Erickson (1982) described self-transcendence as anon-ego-
  centric understandingof the world. Although our conception of
  STE may involve a decreasingly ego-centric spatial frame of
  reference, it does not assume that there is a change in oneâ€™s
  conceptual understanding of a self-centered perspective on the
  world. Frankl (1966) referred to self-transcendence as aprioriti-
  zation of other peopleover self-focus. Although we suggest that
  altruistic motivation may result from STEs, such other-prioritized
  behavior or thinking is not involved during the STE. Self-
  indexResponse.matches[1].metadata.text=oneâ€™s existence in general. Although such prosocial attitudes and
  motivations may result from an STE, they are not part of the
  transient state of STE we describe here. Other approaches describe
  self-transcendence as apersonality factor(Piedmont, 1999), or a
  developmental processinvolving a maturing capacity for mean-
  ingful connection (Levenson, Jennings, Aldwin, & Shiraishi, 2005;
  Tornstam, 2005). A few approaches describe long-term alterations
  to self-processes calledselflessness(Dambrun & Ricard, 2011;
  Davis & Vago, 2013), whereas here we focus on brief mental
  states. The self-transcendence subscale of the Temperament and
  Character Inventory (TCI; Cloninger, Svrakic, & Przybeck, 1993)
  operationalizes self-transcendence as a trait-like tendency to both
  believeandfeelthat one is part of, rather than apart from, the
  universe as a whole (Garcia-Romeu, 2010). For our purposes, each
  of these characterizations of self-transcendence may be predispos-
  indexResponse.matches[2].metadata.text=Variability in the intensity of perceived unity is apparent in
  several common psychological constructs that researchers have
  claimed contain degrees of self-transcendence. These â€œvarieties of
  self-transcendent experienceâ€ include: the states of mindfulness
  (Davidson et al., 2003; Kabat-Zinn, 1994), flow (Csikszentmi-
  halyi, 1991), self-transcendent positive emotions such as love and
  awe (Haidt, 2003; Haidt & Morris, 2009; Keltner & Haidt, 2003;
  Van Cappellen, & Rime, 2014), peak experiences (Maslow, 1964),
  and â€œmysticalâ€ experiences (Hood, 1975, 2003; James, 1902;
  Newberg & dâ€™Aquili, 2000). Each of these otherwise quite differ-
  ent constructs has been described in theoretical writing and in
  psychometric scales as having aspects related to reduced self-
  salience and/or enhanced connectedness.
  The designation â€œself-transcendent experienceâ€ (STE) works
  best for our purposes because it captures a spectrum of intensities
  in addition to remaining neutral regarding secular or spiritual

LOG 3
=====
FROM OUR FIRST RUN SUBMITTING DOC EXCERPTS TO CHATGPT 3.5 (TWO QUERIES):

Jun 16 03:45:22 PM  ==> Starting service with 'node index.js'
Jun 16 03:45:25 PM  Your service is live ðŸŽ‰
Jun 16 03:45:24 PM  searchAIapi listening on port 44444

QUERY 1
-------
Jun 16 03:48:51 PM  chatbot=chatbot_transcendence
Jun 16 03:48:51 PM  namespace=Varieties of Transcendence
Jun 16 03:48:54 PM  {"role":"user","content":"So ordinary incremental growth is like Kuhn's evolutionary phase, whereas transformation is like Kuhn's revolutionary phase, right?"}
Jun 16 03:48:54 PM  {"role":"user","content":"So ordinary incremental growth is like Kuhn's evolutionary phase, whereas transformation is like Kuhn's revolutionary phase, right?\n\nDocuments:\n\n1. the extent to which one feels boundaries fall away between\noneself and the surrounding environment. This dimension can\nbe demonstrated by a commonly used measure to assess the\ndegree to which an individual feels connected to other people or\noneâ€™s environment (Aron, Aron, & Smollan, 1992; see Figure\n1).\nSelf-transcendence has been variously conceptualized in the\npsychological literature in ways that arenotrelevant to our defi-\nnition. Erickson (1982) described self-transcendence as anon-ego-\ncentric understandingof the world. Although our conception of\nSTE may involve a decreasingly ego-centric spatial frame of\nreference, it does not assume that there is a change in oneâ€™s\nconceptual understanding of a self-centered perspective on the\nworld. Frankl (1966) referred to self-transcendence as aprioriti-\nzation of other peopleover self-focus. Although we suggest that\naltruistic motivation may result from STEs, such other-prioritized\nbehavior or thinking is not involved during the STE. Self-\n\n2. Variability in the intensity of perceived unity is apparent in\nseveral common psychological constructs that researchers have\nclaimed contain degrees of self-transcendence. These â€œvarieties of\nself-transcendent experienceâ€ include: the states of mindfulness\n(Davidson et al., 2003; Kabat-Zinn, 1994), flow (Csikszentmi-\nhalyi, 1991), self-transcendent positive emotions such as love and\nawe (Haidt, 2003; Haidt & Morris, 2009; Keltner & Haidt, 2003;\nVan Cappellen, & Rime, 2014), peak experiences (Maslow, 1964),\nand â€œmysticalâ€ experiences (Hood, 1975, 2003; James, 1902;\nNewberg & dâ€™Aquili, 2000). Each of these otherwise quite differ-\nent constructs has been described in theoretical writing and in\npsychometric scales as having aspects related to reduced self-\nsalience and/or enhanced connectedness.\nThe designation â€œself-transcendent experienceâ€ (STE) works\nbest for our purposes because it captures a spectrum of intensities\nin addition to remaining neutral regarding secular or spiritual\n\n3. oneâ€™s existence in general. Although such prosocial attitudes and\nmotivations may result from an STE, they are not part of the\ntransient state of STE we describe here. Other approaches describe\nself-transcendence as apersonality factor(Piedmont, 1999), or a\ndevelopmental processinvolving a maturing capacity for mean-\ningful connection (Levenson, Jennings, Aldwin, & Shiraishi, 2005;\nTornstam, 2005). A few approaches describe long-term alterations\nto self-processes calledselflessness(Dambrun & Ricard, 2011;\nDavis & Vago, 2013), whereas here we focus on brief mental\nstates. The self-transcendence subscale of the Temperament and\nCharacter Inventory (TCI; Cloninger, Svrakic, & Przybeck, 1993)\noperationalizes self-transcendence as a trait-like tendency to both\nbelieveandfeelthat one is part of, rather than apart from, the\nuniverse as a whole (Garcia-Romeu, 2010). Jun 16 03:54:07 PM  {"role":"user","content":"What are the defining characteristics of self-transcendent experiences?"}
Jun 16 03:54:07 PM  {"role":"user","content":"What are the defining characteristics of self-transcendent experiences?\n\nDocuments:\n\n1. Variability in the intensity of perceived unity is apparent in\nseveral common psychological constructs that researchers have\nclaimed contain degrees of self-transcendence. These â€œvarieties of\nself-transcendent experienceâ€ include: the states of mindfulness\n(Davidson et al., 2003; Kabat-Zinn, 1994), flow (Csikszentmi-\nhalyi, 1991), self-transcendent positive emotions such as love and\nawe (Haidt, 2003; Haidt & Morris, 2009; Keltner & Haidt, 2003;\nVan Cappellen, & Rime, 2014), peak experiences (Maslow, 1964),\nand â€œmysticalâ€ experiences (Hood, 1975, 2003; James, 1902;\nNewberg & dâ€™Aquili, 2000). Each of these otherwise quite differ-\nent constructs has been described in theoretical writing and in\npsychometric scales as having aspects related to reduced self-\nsalience and/or enhanced connectedness.\nThe designation â€œself-transcendent experienceâ€ (STE) works\nbest for our purposes because it captures a spectrum of intensities\nin addition to remaining neutral regarding secular or spiritual\n\n2. the extent to which one feels boundaries fall away between\noneself and the surrounding environment. This dimension can\nbe demonstrated by a commonly used measure to assess the\ndegree to which an individual feels connected to other people or\noneâ€™s environment (Aron, Aron, & Smollan, 1992; see Figure\n1).\nSelf-transcendence has been variously conceptualized in the\npsychological literature in ways that arenotrelevant to our defi-\nnition. Erickson (1982) described self-transcendence as anon-ego-\ncentric understandingof the world. Although our conception of\nSTE may involve a decreasingly ego-centric spatial frame of\nreference, it does not assume that there is a change in oneâ€™s\nconceptual understanding of a self-centered perspective on the\nworld. Frankl (1966) referred to self-transcendence as aprioriti-\nzation of other peopleover self-focus. Although we suggest that\naltruistic motivation may result from STEs, such other-prioritized\nbehavior or thinking is not involved during the STE. Self-\n\n3. used by others to describe a generalized reduction of self-\ncenteredness and selfish motivations. Many religious, spiritual,\nand philosophically secular moral systems, for example, advocate\nself-transcendent ideals that prioritize serving others above the self\n(Shariff, Norenzayan, & Henrich, 2010). Here, however, our in-\nterest is exclusively on phenomenologicalexperiencesof self-\ntranscendenceâ€”not beliefs, values, or orientations (though these\nare likely influenced by STE).\nOur definition of STEâ€”transient mental states of decreased\nself-salience and/or increased feelings of connectednessâ€”includes\ntwo broad complementary subcomponents worth decomposing: (a)\nan â€œannhilationalâ€ component, which refers to both the dissolution\nThis document is copyrighted by the American Psychological Association or one of its allied publishers.\nThis article is intended solely for the personal use of the individual user and is not to be disseminated broadly.\n2\nYADEN ET AL."}
